comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content:
Curtis the pawnbroker and his shop are mentioned in the Freeman's (March 2 1894) report of The Meath Murder trial (Warning: contains the word 'bosom')
James Curtis, pawnbroker, Drogheda, deposed that the shirt (produced) was pawned in his establishment by a man who gave the name of Gallagher. He believed the prisoner was the man.

comment.author: 60812213@N04
comment._content: Maybe one of them took several pictures and sold a plate to the other, or swapped for another location.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: PS. Meath Murder - Gallagher was acquitted at the summer assizes at Trim in July following a rousing speech by Mr Ennis the defence barrister. Summer Assizes

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/abandonedrailsireland] That sounds more plausible than two unrelated photographers deciding to take the same photo at the same time on the same day.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Bass Pale Ale is well known (even at the Folie-Bergeres!), but I can't find any references to a Bass Ten Guinea Ale.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] I've found several newspaper adverts for Ten Guinea Ale, in newspapers in Bristol, Birmingham and Dundee, (Garton's Ten Guinea Ale, Edinburgh Ten Guinea Ale, Dryburgh's Ten Guinea Ale etc) but the only references to Bass Ten Guinea Ale are in Freeman's. There was one advert which also listed Seven Guinea Ale and Five Guinea Ale. I'm guessing that the ten guineas refers to the the amount of duty payable (per firkin?), and that the duty was introduced in about 1860, because most of the adverts are from 1860-61. Interestingly most of the later adverts (1889ish) are in Scottish newspapers, and in Scotland they still have 50/- and 70/- ale. Edit: it seems my guess about the duty was wrong,.
